- But unfortunately we don’t know much about how far over the line this behavior might have been. It’s very safe to assume that the toilet story, while tantalizing (well, not tantalizing exactly) is probably a nonstarter. After all, while one might assume that Trump was disposing of material that should have been retained during his presidency, we don’t know that for sure. We don’t know Trump placed the paper in the toilet or that it was anything subject to retention rules. And the nature of the incident means we’ll never know. - There’s a political angle to this as well, of course. Trump repeatedly harangued Hillary Clinton during the 2016 campaign for her use of a private email server while she served in the Obama administration. He often misrepresented and exaggerated her actions, but some material on the server was determined to have been classified. The Justice Department determined that there was “no persuasive evidence of systemic, deliberate mishandling of classified information,” and Clinton — to Trump’s oft-performed chagrin — faced no criminal charges. - While President Trump was in office, staff in the White House residence periodically discovered wads of printed paper clogging a toilet — and believed the president had flushed pieces of paper, Maggie Haberman scoops in her forthcoming book, " Confidence Man . Reference: https://www.axios.com/2022/02/10/maggie-haberman-book-trump-papers published on 2022-02-10 13:54:49
correction_response:
This tweet is potentially misleading. Misprision requires both concealment of a felony and failure to notify federal authorities. Haberman's reporting of Trump's actions doesn't necessarily constitute concealment, and it's unclear if she had a legal obligation to report these actions to authorities. Furthermore, it's not confirmed that the papers Trump allegedly flushed were subject to retention rules or constituted a felony. Lastly, the misprision statute could be seen as encouraging arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement, which could be unconstitutional. 
References: 
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/09/29/misprision-of-felony/
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/02/10/breaking-law-via-toilet-would-certainly-complete-one-trump-era-story-arc/
note_1_text: For someone to be guilty of the federal crime of misprision of a felony, they must have taken an affirmative step to conceal the alleged felony.     There is no indication that Haberman took any such step, or that this law would apply to her First Amendment-protected reporting.     https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/4
note_2_text: This claim is false. Misprision requires an affirmative act of concealment. For ex, if you see someone break a jewelry store window and steal a diamond, not reporting the damage/theft isn’t misprision. Helping clean up the shattered glass so no one knows what happened is.    https://www.ce9.uscourts.gov/jury-instructions/node/1159    https://casetext.com/statute/united-states-code/title-18-crimes-and-criminal-procedure/part-i-crimes/chapter-1-general-provisions/section-4-misprision-of-felony/analysis?citingPage=1&sort=relevance&sortCiting=date-ascending

- Haberman — who obtained the photos recently — shared them with us ahead of the Oct. 4 publication of her book, " Confidence Man : The Making of Donald Trump and the Breaking of America." Reference: https://www.axios.com/2022/08/08/trump-toilet-photos-maggie-haberman published on 2022-08-08 09:50:34

- In order to be guilty of misprision, a defendant must both conceal a felony and also fail to notify federal authorities of that crime. The misprision statute “would be unconstitutional under the Fifth Amendment if, and to the extent, it required a defendant to report her own criminal conduct to the authorities.” Reference: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/09/29/misprision-of-felony/ published on 2014-09-29 12:52:16

- That’s quite likely why Haberman’s story broke now; the subject is in the news. Reference: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/02/10/breaking-law-via-toilet-would-certainly-complete-one-trump-era-story-arc/ published on 2022-02-10 16:21:47

- That scene came to mind last week with the news — in a tease from New York Times reporter Maggie Haberman for her forthcoming book about Donald Trump — that “White House residence staff periodically found papers had clogged a toilet, leaving staff believing Trump had flushed material he’d ripped into pieces.” Reference: https://thehill.com/opinion/white-house/594278-document-dump-turns-toxic-for-trump/ published on 2022-02-15 16:30:06

tweet_text: I’m not a journalist, so I can’t say whether Maggie Haberman is doing her job appropriately. I am a lawyer, though, so I can say her failure to report Trump’s felonies upon discovering them — saving them for her book instead — appears to be misprision, which is itself a felony.
